channel.title: IT-Security & Privacy News Aggregator
channel.description: Aggregierter RSS-Feed aus führenden IT-Security, Privacy und Cyber Policy Quellen

item.title: GISEC GLOBAL 2026 – The Middle East &amp; Africa’s Largest Cybersecurity Event
Venezuelan Oil Company Downplays Alleged US Cyberattack
item.description: But media reports described the attack as causing major disruption to PDVSA, the state-owned oil and natural gas company.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: Russia Hits Critical Orgs Via Misconfigured Edge Devices
item.description: Amazon detailed a long-running campaign by Russia against critical infrastructure organizations, particularly in the energy sector.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Urban VPN Proxy Accused of Harvesting AI Chat Conversations
item.description: The browser extension Urban VPN Proxy has been reportedly collecting users’ AI chat conversations

item.title: Compromised IAM Credentials Power a Large AWS Crypto Mining Campaign
item.description: An ongoing campaign has been observed targeting Amazon Web Services (AWS) customers using compromised Identity and Access Management (IAM) credentials to enable cryptocurrency mining. The activity, first detected by Amazon's GuardDuty managed threat detection service and its automated security monitoring systems on November 2, 2025, employs never-before-seen persistence techniques to hamper
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Browser Extension Harvests 8M Users' AI Chatbot Data
item.description: Urban VPN Proxy, which claims to protect users' privacy, collects data from conversations with ChatGPT, Claude, Gemini, Copilot and other AI assistants.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: JumpCloud Windows Agent Flaw Enables Local Privilege Escalation
item.description: A flaw in JumpCloud Remote Assist for Windows has exposed managed endpoints to local privilege escalation and denial-of-service attacks

item.title: Rogue NuGet Package Poses as Tracer.Fody, Steals Cryptocurrency Wallet Data
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered a new malicious NuGet package that typosquats and impersonates the popular .NET tracing library and its author to sneak in a cryptocurrency wallet stealer. The malicious package, named "Tracer.Fody.NLog," remained on the repository for nearly six years. It was published by a user named "csnemess" on February 26, 2020. It masquerades as "Tracer.Fody,"
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Enterprises Gear Up for 2026’s IT Transformation
item.description: Experts predict big changes are coming for IT infrastructure in 2026 driven by AI adoption, hybrid cloud strategies, and evolving security demands.
item.dc:creator: Arielle Waldman

item.title: Most Parked Domains Now Serving Malicious Content
item.description: Direct navigation -- the act of visiting a website by manually typing a domain name in a web browser -- has never been riskier: A new study finds the vast majority of "parked" domains -- mostly expired or dormant domain names, or common misspellings of popular websites -- are now configured to redirect visitors to sites that foist scams and malware.
item.dc:creator: BrianKrebs

item.title: Amazon Exposes Years-Long GRU Cyber Campaign Targeting Energy and Cloud Infrastructure
item.description: Amazon's threat intelligence team has disclosed details of a "years-long" Russian state-sponsored campaign that targeted Western critical infrastructure between 2021 and 2025. Targets of the campaign included energy sector organizations across Western nations, critical infrastructure providers in North America and Europe, and entities with cloud-hosted network infrastructure. The activity has
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Amazon Warns Russian GRU Hackers Target Western Firms via Edge Devices
item.description: Amazon researchers believe this campaign is part of a bigger operation spearheaded by Russia’s military intelligence service, the GRU

item.title: Chinese Surveillance and AI
item.description: <p>New report: &#8220;<a href="https://aspi.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/11/27122307/The-partys-AI-How-Chinas-new-AI-systems-are-reshaping-human-rights.pdf">The Party&#8217;s AI: How China&#8217;s New AI Systems are Reshaping Human Rights</a>.&#8221; From a <a href="https://www.aspi.org.au/report/the-partys-ai-how-chinas-new-ai-systems-are-reshaping-human-rights/">summary article</a>:</p> <blockquote><p>China is already the world&#8217;s largest exporter of AI powered surveillance technology; new surveillance technologies and platforms developed in China are also not likely to simply stay there. By exposing the full scope of China&#8217;s AI driven control apparatus, this report presents clear, evidence based insights for policymakers, civil society, the media and technology companies seeking to counter the rise of AI enabled repression and human rights violations, and China&#8217;s growing efforts to project that repression beyond its borders...</p></blockquote>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Why Data Security and Privacy Need to Start in Code
item.description: AI-assisted coding and AI app generation platforms have created an unprecedented surge in software development. Companies are now facing rapid growth in both the number of applications and the pace of change within those applications. Security and privacy teams are under significant pressure as the surface area they must cover is expanding quickly while their staffing levels remain largely
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Fortinet FortiGate Under Active Attack Through SAML SSO Authentication Bypass
item.description: Threat actors have begun to exploit two newly disclosed security flaws in Fortinet FortiGate devices, less than a week after public disclosure. Cybersecurity company Arctic Wolf said it observed active intrusions involving malicious single sign-on (SSO) logins on FortiGate appliances on December 12, 2025. The attacks exploit two critical authentication bypasses (CVE-2025-59718 and CVE-2025-59719
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Google to Kill Popular Dark Web Report Tool
item.description: <p>This marks another abrupt end to a Google service that users had come to rely on. </p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-google-kills-dark-web-report-tool/">Google to Kill Popular Dark Web Report Tool</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: Millions of Car Owners Hit By Credit700 Data Breach
item.description: US financial services firm Credit700 has revealed a major data breach impacting 5.8 million people

item.title: Phishing Messages and Social Scams Flood Users Ahead of Christmas
item.description: Check Point has detected thousands of phishing emails in the past fortnight, offering fake promotions and special deals

item.title: Coupang CEO Quits After Breach Hits 33.7M South Koreans
item.description: <p>The e-commerce firm's data breach exposed nearly two-thirds of the entire country's population after hackers operated undetected for five months.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-coupang-ceo-quits/">Coupang CEO Quits After Breach Hits 33.7M South Koreans</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: React2Shell Vulnerability Actively Exploited to Deploy Linux Backdoors
item.description: The security vulnerability known as React2Shell is being exploited by threat actors to deliver malware families like KSwapDoor and ZnDoor, according to findings from Palo Alto Networks Unit 42 and NTT Security. "KSwapDoor is a professionally engineered remote access tool designed with stealth in mind," Justin Moore, senior manager of threat intel research at Palo Alto Networks Unit 42, said in a
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Google to Shut Down Dark Web Monitoring Tool in February 2026
item.description: Google has announced that it's discontinuing its dark web report tool in February 2026, less than two years after it was launched as a way for users to monitor if their personal information is found on the dark web. To that end, scans for new dark web breaches will be stopped on January 15, 2026, and the feature will cease to exist effective February 16, 2026. "While the report offered general
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: How Cyber Insurance MGAs Shape Policies for Evolving Cyber-Risks
item.description: Managing general agents help insurers navigate sectors where they lack expertise. A cybersecurity policy written by an MGA is more likely to reflect an understanding of the risks CISOs deal with.
item.dc:creator: Ericka Chickowski, Contributing Writer

item.title: Apple Patches More Zero-Days Used in 'Sophisticated' Attack
item.description: Two Apple zero-day vulnerabilities discovered this month have overlap with another mysterious zero-day flaw Google patched last week.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Think Like an Attacker: Cybersecurity Tips From a CISO
item.description: Etay Mayor, a cybersecurity strategist and professor, shares his journey, insights, and advice on breaking into the diverse and ever-evolving field of cybersecurity.
item.dc:creator: Kristina Beek

item.title: Featured Chrome Browser Extension Caught Intercepting Millions of Users' AI Chats
item.description: A Google Chrome extension with a "Featured" badge and six million users has been observed silently gathering every prompt entered by users into artificial intelligence (AI)-powered chatbots like OpenAI ChatGPT, Anthropic Claude, Microsoft Copilot, DeepSeek, Google Gemini, xAI Grok, Meta AI, and Perplexity. The extension in question is Urban VPN Proxy, which has a 4.7 rating on the Google Chrome
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Third Defendant Pleads Guilty in Fantasy Sports Betting Hack Case
item.description: A Minnesota man has pleaded guilty to a credential stuffing scheme that compromised over 60,000 accounts

item.title: Russian Phishing Campaign Delivers Phantom Stealer Via ISO Files
item.description: A new phishing campaign has been identified, delivering the Phantom information-stealing malware via an ISO attachment

item.title: Flaw in Hacktivist Ransomware Lets Victims Decrypt Own Files
item.description: A new version of VolkLocker, wielded by the pro-Russia RaaS group CyberVolk, has some key enhancements but one fatal flaw.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: Meet the Council’s New Client Engagement Operations Director
item.dc:creator: amalone@pcisecuritystandards.org (Alicia Malone)

item.title: FreePBX Patches Critical SQLi, File-Upload, and AUTHTYPE Bypass Flaws Enabling RCE
item.description:
Multiple security vulnerabilities have been disclosed in the open-source private branch exchange (PBX) platform FreePBX, including a critical flaw that could result in an authentication bypass under certain configurations. The shortcomings, discovered by Horizon3.ai and reported to the project maintainers on September 15, 2025, are listed below -
CVE-2025-61675 (CVSS score: 8.6) - Numerous
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: ⚡ Weekly Recap: Apple 0-Days, WinRAR Exploit, LastPass Fines, .NET RCE, OAuth Scams & More
item.description: If you use a smartphone, browse the web, or unzip files on your computer, you are in the crosshairs this week. Hackers are currently exploiting critical flaws in the daily software we all rely on—and in some cases, they started attacking before a fix was even ready. Below, we list the urgent updates you need to install right now to stop these active threats. ⚡ Threat of the Week Apple and
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Against the Federal Moratorium on State-Level Regulation of AI
item.description: <p>Cast your mind back to May of this year: Congress was in the throes of debate over the massive <a href="https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/house-bill/1">budget bill</a>. Amidst the many seismic provisions, Senator Ted Cruz <a href="https://iapp.org/news/a/policy-analysis-us-house-committee-seeks-moratorium-on-state-AI-rules">dropped</a> a ticking time bomb of tech policy: a ten-year moratorium on the ability of states to regulate artificial intelligence. To many, this was catastrophic. The few massive AI companies seem to be swallowing our economy whole: their energy demands are overriding household needs, their data demands are overriding creators&#8217; copyright, and their products are triggering mass unemployment as well as new types of clinical ...</p>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: A Browser Extension Risk Guide After the ShadyPanda Campaign
item.description: In early December 2025, security researchers exposed a cybercrime campaign that had quietly hijacked popular Chrome and Edge browser extensions on a massive scale. A threat group dubbed ShadyPanda spent seven years playing the long game, publishing or acquiring harmless extensions, letting them run clean for years to build trust and gain millions of installs, then suddenly flipping them into
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Apple Releases macOS Sequoia 15.7.3 Security Update
item.description: <p>Apple has released macOS Sequoia 15.7.3 with important security fixes. Here’s what to know before installing the update.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-apple-macos-sequoia-security-update/">Apple Releases macOS Sequoia 15.7.3 Security Update</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Kezia Jungco

item.title: Asahi to Launch Cybersecurity Overhaul After Crippling Cyber-Attack
item.description: Asahi Group’s CEO said he is considering creating a dedicated cyber unit following the ransomware attack that crippled the company

item.title: Are Your AI Assistants Under Attack?
item.description: <p>Many users utilize an AI assistant to handle their inbox, leaving them vulnerable to attack. </p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-ai-assistants-under-attack/">Are Your AI Assistants Under Attack?</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Drew Robb

item.title: Top 25 Most Dangerous Software Weaknesses of 2025 Revealed
item.description: MITRE has released its Top 25 CWE list for 2025, compiled from software and hardware flaws behind almost 40,000 CVEs

item.title: NCSC Playbook Embeds Cyber Essentials in Supply Chains
item.description: The UK’s National Cyber Security Centre has called on businesses to apply Cyber Essentials to suppliers

item.title: Phantom Stealer Spread by ISO Phishing Emails Hitting Russian Finance Sector
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of an active phishing campaign that's targeting a wide range of sectors in Russia with phishing emails that deliver Phantom Stealer via malicious ISO optical disc images. The activity, codenamed Operation MoneyMount-ISO by Seqrite Labs, has primarily singled out finance and accounting entities, with those in the procurement, legal, payroll
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: ServiceNow Mulls $7B Armis Cybersecurity Acquisition
item.description: <p>The deal could be announced within days, according to Bloomberg.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-servicenow-armis-deal/">ServiceNow Mulls $7B Armis Cybersecurity Acquisition</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: VolkLocker Ransomware Exposed by Hard-Coded Master Key Allowing Free Decryption
item.description: The pro-Russian hacktivist group known as CyberVolk (aka GLORIAMIST) has resurfaced with a new ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) offering called VolkLocker that suffers from implementation lapses in test artifacts, allowing users to decrypt files without paying an extortion fee. According to SentinelOne, VolkLocker (aka CyberVolk 2.x) emerged in August 2025 and is capable of targeting both Windows
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Understanding and Mitigating CVE-2025-55182 (React2Shell) | UpGuard
item.description: CVE-2025-55182 is a critical unauthenticated RCE in React Server Components (CVSS 10.0). Check if your Next.js or React 19 app is vulnerable and patch now.

item.title: What is Cybersecurity Risk? A Thorough Definition | UpGuard
item.description: Cybersecurity risk is the risk of a cyber attack or data breach on your organization.

item.title: Upcoming Speaking Engagements
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: CISA Adds Actively Exploited Sierra Wireless Router Flaw Enabling RCE Attacks
item.description: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Friday added a high-severity flaw impacting Sierra Wireless AirLink ALEOS routers to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, following reports of active exploitation in the wild. CVE-2018-4063 (CVSS score: 8.8/9.9) refers to an unrestricted file upload vulnerability that could be exploited to achieve remote code
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Apple Issues Security Updates After Two WebKit Flaws Found Exploited in the Wild
item.description:
Apple on Friday released security updates for iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, watchOS, visionOS, and its Safari web browser to address two security flaws that it said have been exploited in the wild, one of which is the same flaw that was patched by Google in Chrome earlier this week. The vulnerabilities are listed below -
CVE-2025-43529 (CVSS score: N/A) - A use-after-free vulnerability in WebKit
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Friday Squid Blogging: Giant Squid Eating a Diamondback Squid
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: The CISO-COO Partnership: Protecting Operational Excellence
item.description: Digital transformation has made cybersecurity preparation part of operational resilience for most organizations. This calls for a new relationship between CISOs and COOs.
item.dc:creator: George V. Hulme, Contributing Writer

item.title: React2Shell Exploits Flood the Internet as Attacks Continue
item.description: As exploitation activity against CVE-2025-55182 ramps up, researchers are finding some proof-of-concept exploits contain bypasses for web application firewall (WAF) rules.
item.dc:creator: Rob Wright

item.title: Vibe Coding: Innovation Demands Vigilance
item.description: Unmanaged coding is indeed an alluring idea, but can introduce a host of significant cybersecurity dangers, Constantine warns.
item.dc:creator: Chrissa Constantine

item.title: Microsoft Will Bundle Security Copilot With M365 Enterprise Licenses
item.description: The move aims to expand the use of Security Copilot and comes with the launch of 12 new agents from Microsoft at the company's Ignite conference last week.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Schwartz

item.title: Fake OSINT and GPT Utility GitHub Repos Spread PyStoreRAT Malware Payloads
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers are calling attention to a new campaign that's leveraging GitHub-hosted Python repositories to distribute a previously undocumented JavaScript-based Remote Access Trojan (RAT) dubbed PyStoreRAT. "These repositories, often themed as development utilities or OSINT tools, contain only a few lines of code responsible for silently downloading a remote HTA file and executing
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Supply Chain Attacks Targeting GitHub Actions Increased in 2025
item.description: At this week's Black Hat Europe conference, two researchers urged developers to adopt a shared responsibility model for open source software and not leave it all up to GitHub to handle.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Schwartz

item.title: 7 Tech Predictions Enterprise Leaders Are Watching in 2026
item.description: <p>Industry leaders share their 2026 tech predictions, covering AI at scale, cloud autonomy, security risk, observability, governance, and operational pressure.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-2026-tech-predictions-industry-experts/">7 Tech Predictions Enterprise Leaders Are Watching in 2026</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Liz Ticong

item.title: Black Hat Europe 2025: Was that device designed to be on the internet at all?
item.description: Behind the polished exterior of many modern buildings sit outdated systems with vulnerabilities waiting to be found

item.title: New Advanced Phishing Kits Use AI and MFA Bypass Tactics to Steal Credentials at Scale
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have documented four new phishing kits named BlackForce, GhostFrame, InboxPrime AI, and Spiderman that are capable of facilitating credential theft at scale. BlackForce, first detected in August 2025, is designed to steal credentials and perform Man-in-the-Browser (MitB) attacks to capture one-time passwords (OTPs) and bypass multi-factor authentication (MFA). The kit
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Are Trade Concerns Trumping US Cybersecurity?
item.description: The Trump administration appears to have dropped sanctions against Chinese actors for the Salt Typhoon attacks on US telecoms; but focusing on diplomacy alone misses the full picture, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: Building Trustworthy AI Agents
item.description: <p>The promise of personal AI assistants rests on a dangerous assumption: that we can trust systems we haven’t made trustworthy. We can’t. And today’s versions are failing us in predictable ways: pushing us to do things against our own best interests, gaslighting us with doubt about things we are or that we know, and being unable to distinguish between who we are and who we have been. They struggle with incomplete, inaccurate, and partial context: with no standard way to move toward accuracy, no mechanism to correct sources of error, and no accountability when wrong information leads to bad decisions...</p>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: NCSC Plugs Gap in Cyber-Deception Guidance
item.description: The National Cyber Security Centre has released new learnings from a cyber deception pilot

item.title: Securing GenAI in the Browser: Policy, Isolation, and Data Controls That Actually Work
item.description: The browser has become the main interface to GenAI for most enterprises: from web-based LLMs and copilots, to GenAI‑powered extensions and agentic browsers like ChatGPT Atlas. Employees are leveraging the power of GenAI to draft emails, summarize documents, work on code, and analyze data, often by copying/pasting sensitive information directly into prompts or uploading files.&nbsp; Traditional
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: ICO Fines LastPass £1.2m After 2022 Breach
item.description: The UK’s data protection regulator has fined password manager provider LastPass £1.2m after 2022 data breach

item.title: New React RSC Vulnerabilities Enable DoS and Source Code Exposure
item.description: The React team has released fixes for two new types of flaws in React Server Components (RSC) that, if successfully exploited, could result in denial-of-service (DoS) or source code exposure. The team said the issues were found by the security community while attempting to exploit the patches released for CVE-2025-55182 (CVSS score: 10.0), a critical bug in RSC that has since been weaponized in
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: React2Shell Exploitation Escalates into Large-Scale Global Attacks, Forcing Emergency Mitigation
item.description: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has urged federal agencies to patch the recent React2Shell vulnerability by December 12, 2025, amid reports of widespread exploitation. The critical vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-55182 (CVSS score: 10.0), affects the React Server Components (RSC) Flight protocol. The underlying cause of the issue is an unsafe deserialization
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Hamas-Linked Hackers Probe Middle Eastern Diplomats
item.description: Hamas's best hackers have been maturing, building better malware, and spreading their attacks more widely across the region.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: CISA Flags Actively Exploited GeoServer XXE Flaw in Updated KEV Catalog
item.description: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Thursday added a high-severity security flaw impacting OSGeo GeoServer to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, based on evidence of active exploitation in the wild. The vulnerability in question is CVE-2025-58360 (CVSS score: 8.2), an unauthenticated XML External Entity (XXE) flaw that affects all versions prior to
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Money Mules Require Banks to Switch From Defense to Offense
item.description: Financial institutions must be proactive when identifying and preventing fraudulent activity. Here are five &quot;mule personas&quot; to watch for.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Frost

item.title: Encouraging Industry Voices to Write for the Commentary Section
item.description: Dark Reading will continue to publish Tech Talks and Ask the Expert pieces in the Commentary section. Read on for submission guidelines.
item.dc:creator: Fahmida Y. Rashid

item.title: Attackers Exploited Gogs Zero-Day Flaw for Months
item.description: Wiz disclosed a still-unpatched vulnerability in self-hosted Git service Gogs, which is a bypass for a previous RCE bug disclosed last year.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: AIs Exploiting Smart Contracts
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Black Hat Europe 2025: Reputation matters – even in the ransomware economy
item.description: Being seen as reliable is good for ‘business’ and ransomware groups care about 'brand reputation' just as much as their victims

item.title: AI in OT Sparks Cascade of Complex Challenges
item.description: Using artificial intelligence in operational technology environments could be a bumpy ride full of trust issues and security challenges.
item.dc:creator: Arielle Waldman

item.title: ThreatsDay Bulletin: Spyware Alerts, Mirai Strikes, Docker Leaks, ValleyRAT Rootkit — and 20 More Stories
item.description: This week’s cyber stories show how fast the online world can turn risky. Hackers are sneaking malware into movie downloads, browser add-ons, and even software updates people trust. Tech giants and governments are racing to plug new holes while arguing over privacy and control. And researchers keep uncovering just how much of our digital life is still wide open. The new Threatsday Bulletin
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: NANOREMOTE Malware Uses Google Drive API for Hidden Control on Windows Systems
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new fully-featured Windows backdoor called NANOREMOTE that uses the Google Drive API for command-and-control (C2) purposes. According to a report from Elastic Security Labs, the malware shares code similarities with another implant codenamed FINALDRAFT (aka Squidoor) that employs Microsoft Graph API for C2. FINALDRAFT is attributed to a
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: The Impact of Robotic Process Automation (RPA) on Identity and Access Management
item.description: As enterprises refine their strategies for handling Non-Human Identities (NHIs), Robotic Process Automation (RPA) has become a powerful tool for streamlining operations and enhancing security. However, since RPA bots have varying levels of access to sensitive information, enterprises must be prepared to mitigate a variety of challenges. In large organizations, bots are starting to outnumber
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: GeminiJack Zero-Click Flaw Exposed Millions of Users in Google Workspace AI
item.description: <p>Noma Labs uncovers GeminiJack, a zero-click flaw where hidden instructions in shared Workspace files could steer Gemini Enterprise and leak corporate data.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-geminijack-zero-click-flaw/">GeminiJack Zero-Click Flaw Exposed Millions of Users in Google Workspace AI</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Liz Ticong

item.title: WIRTE Leverages AshenLoader Sideloading to Install the AshTag Espionage Backdoor
item.description: An advanced persistent threat (APT) known as WIRTE has been attributed to attacks targeting government and diplomatic entities across the Middle East with a previously undocumented malware suite dubbed AshTag since 2020. Palo Alto Networks Unit 42 is tracking the activity cluster under the name Ashen Lepus. Artifacts uploaded to the VirusTotal platform show that the threat actor has trained its
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Unpatched Gogs Zero-Day Exploited Across 700+ Instances Amid Active Attacks
item.description: A high-severity unpatched security vulnerability in Gogs has come under active exploitation, with more than 700 compromised instances accessible over the internet, according to new findings from Wiz. The flaw, tracked as CVE-2025-8110 (CVSS score: 8.7), is a case of file overwrite in the file update API of the Go-based self-hosted Git service. A fix for the issue is said to be currently in the
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Copilot's No-Code AI Agents Liable to Leak Company Data
item.description: Microsoft puts the power of AI in the hands of everyday non-technical Joes. It's a nice idea, and a surefire recipe for security issues.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: Locks, SOCs and a cat in a box: What Schrödinger can teach us about cybersecurity
item.description: If you don’t look inside your environment, you can’t know its true state – and attackers count on that

item.title: Chrome Targeted by Active In-the-Wild Exploit Tied to Undisclosed High-Severity Flaw
item.description: Google on Wednesday shipped security updates for its Chrome browser to address three security flaws, including one it said has come under active exploitation in the wild. The vulnerability, rated high in severity, is being tracked under the Chromium issue tracker ID "466192044." Unlike other disclosures, Google has opted to keep information about the CVE identifier, the affected component, and
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Active Attacks Exploit Gladinet's Hard-Coded Keys for Unauthorized Access and Code Execution
item.description: Huntress is warning of a new actively exploited vulnerability in Gladinet's CentreStack and Triofox products stemming from the use of hard-coded cryptographic keys that have affected nine organizations so far. "Threat actors can potentially abuse this as a way to access the web.config file, opening the door for deserialization and remote code execution," security researcher Bryan Masters said.
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Storm-0249 Abuses EDR Processes in Stealthy Attacks
item.description: The initial access broker has been weaponizing endpoint detection and response (EDR) platforms and Windows utilities in recent high-precision attacks.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: ClickFix Style Attack Uses Grok, ChatGPT for Malware Delivery
item.description: A new twist on the social engineering tactic is making waves, combining SEO poisoning and legitimate AI domains to install malware on victims' computers.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: React2Shell Exploitation Delivers Crypto Miners and New Malware Across Multiple Sectors
item.description: React2Shell continues to witness heavy exploitation, with threat actors leveraging the maximum-severity security flaw in React Server Components (RSC) to deliver cryptocurrency miners and an array of previously undocumented malware families, according to new findings from Huntress. This includes a Linux backdoor called PeerBlight, a reverse proxy tunnel named CowTunnel, and a Go-based
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: .NET SOAPwn Flaw Opens Door for File Writes and Remote Code Execution via Rogue WSDL
item.description: New research has uncovered exploitation primitives in the .NET Framework that could be leveraged against enterprise-grade applications to achieve remote code execution. WatchTowr Labs, which has codenamed the "invalid cast vulnerability" SOAPwn, said the issue impacts Barracuda Service Center RMM, Ivanti Endpoint Manager (EPM), and Umbraco 8. But the number of affected vendors is likely to be
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: 2025 in Tech: A Year of Outages, AI Races, and Power Plays
item.description: <p>Explore the 10 biggest tech stories of 2025, from AI megacenters and space-powered data centers to record-breaking breaches, outages, and satellite showdowns.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-top-10-tech-stories-of-2025/">2025 in Tech: A Year of Outages, AI Races, and Power Plays</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Liz Ticong

item.title: Seeking symmetry during ATT&CK® season: How to harness today’s diverse analyst and tester landscape to paint a security masterpiece
item.description: Interpreting the vast cybersecurity vendor landscape through the lens of industry analysts and testing authorities can immensely enhance your cyber-resilience.

item.title: VITAS Healthcare Breach Exposes 319K Patient Records
item.description: <p>Hackers maintained undetected access to patient systems for over a month, methodically downloading personal and medical information.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-vitas-healthcare-security-breach/">VITAS Healthcare Breach Exposes 319K Patient Records</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: Microsoft’s Patch Tuesday: 57 Flaws Fixed
item.description: <p>KB5072033 addresses vulnerabilities across Windows systems and Office applications—including one actively exploited zero-day.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-microsoft-patch-tuesday-december-2025/">Microsoft’s Patch Tuesday: 57 Flaws Fixed</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: Three PCIe Encryption Weaknesses Expose PCIe 5.0+ Systems to Faulty Data Handling
item.description: Three security vulnerabilities have been disclosed in the Peripheral Component Interconnect Express (PCIe) Integrity and Data Encryption (IDE) protocol specification that could expose a local attacker to serious risks. The flaws impact PCIe Base Specification Revision 5.0 and onwards in the protocol mechanism introduced by the IDE Engineering Change Notice (ECN), according to the PCI Special
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Google Chrome’s New AI Security Aims to Stop Hackers Cold
item.description: <p>Google is also backing these measures with a $20,000 bounty for researchers who can demonstrate successful breaches of the new security boundaries.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-google-chrome-ai-security/">Google Chrome&#8217;s New AI Security Aims to Stop Hackers Cold</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: Remediation Made Easy: Reducing Risks and Driving Vendor Action | UpGuard
item.description: Is your security team lost in the chaos of managing vendor remediation? Learn how UpGuard’s AI can help.

item.title: Feds: Pro-Russia Hacktivists Target US Critical Infrastructure
item.description: So far the attacks, which compromise virtual network computing (VNC) connections in OT systems, have not been particularly destructive, but this could change as they evolve.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: Vendor Responsiveness Solved: Soothing Your Third-Party Aches | UpGuard
item.description: Is waiting on vendor responses slowing down your risk assessments? Learn how UpGuard's AI can help you solve this and other inefficiencies.

item.description: Intelligent compliance management ensures you comply with relevant regulations while strengthening your resilience against cyberattacks.

item.description: Learn the role and responsibilities of a CISO and align your cybersecurity progression pathway against these requirements.

item.title: What are Web Shell Attacks? How to Protect Your Web Servers | UpGuard
item.description: Web shell attacks have doubled between 2021 and 2020. Learn about this threat and how to protect your web server.

item.title: What are Security Ratings? Cybersecurity Risk Scoring Explained | UpGuard
item.description: This is a complete guide to security ratings and common use cases. Learn why security and risk management teams have adopted security ratings in this post.

item.title: FBI Warns of Fake Video Scams
item.description: <p>The FBI is <a href="https://www.ic3.gov/PSA/2025/PSA251205">warning</a> of AI-assisted fake kidnapping scams:</p> <blockquote><p>Criminal actors typically will contact their victims through text message claiming they have kidnapped their loved one and demand a ransom be paid for their release. Oftentimes, the criminal actor will express significant claims of violence towards the loved one if the ransom is not paid immediately. The criminal actor will then send what appears to be a genuine photo or video of the victim&#8217;s loved one, which upon close inspection often reveals inaccuracies when compared to confirmed photos of the loved one. Examples of these inaccuracies include missing tattoos or scars and inaccurate body proportions. Criminal actors will sometimes purposefully send these photos using timed message features to limit the amount of time victims have to analyze the images...</p></blockquote>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Warning: WinRAR Vulnerability CVE-2025-6218 Under Active Attack by Multiple Threat Groups
item.description: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Tuesday added a security flaw impacting the WinRAR file archiver and compression utility to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, citing evidence of active exploitation. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-6218 (CVSS score: 7.8), is a path traversal bug that could enable code execution. However, for exploitation
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
